page.title: 03FARMING IN STOKE DOYLE
page.content: Farming in Stoke Doyle is mainly arable. The main crops are wheat and barley, though sugar-beet, beans and peas and grass are also grown. The fields are planted in rotation. This means that each year a different crop is planted in each field so that the land is not exhausted eg. if last year the field grew barley and this year you grew sugar-beet, then next year you would grow grass. The farms also have animals, mainly sheep and cattle. In the summer the sheep graze on some of the grass fields. The remainder of the grass is cut and used for silage to feed the animals in the winter.The sugar-beet in the area is supplied to the British Sugar Corporation in Peterborough. Each farmer is given a quota which fixes the amount he grows.
